scenarioDescription:
The GJ 317 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 317 is a star with 0.42 times the mass of the Sun, and NaN times its radius. It is located 49.57 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 5 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

GJ 317 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 317 system


GJ 317 b

GJ 317 b was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2007-11, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 1.15 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 317 b is 795.000 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 317 b is 13.300 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, GJ 317 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


GJ 317 c

GJ 317 c was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2016-04, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 5.23 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 317 c is 522.779 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 317 c is 13.500 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, GJ 317 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system GJ 317, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory.
name: GJ 317 - System With 2 Exoplanets
